intro: Monotropa epirrhizium, commonly known as the Indian Pipe, is a rare and enigmatic plant that lacks chlorophyll and is therefore unable to perform photosynthesis. It is a member of the Onagraceae family and is often found in shaded, moist forest environments. This plant forms a symbiotic relationship with mycorrhizal fungi, which provide it with nutrients in exchange for carbohydrates. Its ghostly white appearance and lack of leaves make it easily recognizable in its natural habitat. Despite its unusual appearance, it plays a unique role in forest ecosystems as a myco-heterotroph.
